qas.question: In 1999 how many children were working illegally in Brazil?
What do drug cartels do with child workers?

answers.text: sell and carry drugs, guns, and other illegal substances

qas.question: What are the risks of child labour in drug cartels?
Has these dangers caused and increase or decrease in child labour with drug cartels?

context: Brazilian census data (PNAD, 1999) indicate that <a0_0>2.55 million<a0_0/> 10-14 year-olds were illegally holding jobs. They were joined by 3.7 million 15-17 year-olds and about 375,000 5-9 year-olds. Due to the raised age restriction of 14, at least half of the recorded young workers had been employed illegally which lead to many not being protect by important labour laws. Although substantial time has passed since the time of regulated child labour, there is still a large number of children working illegally in Brazil. Many children are used by drug cartels to <a1_0>sell and carry drugs, guns, and other illegal substances<a1_0/> because of their perception of innocence. This type of work that youth are taking part in is very dangerous due to the <a2_0>physical and psychological implications<a2_0/> that come with these jobs. Yet despite the hazards that come with working with drug dealers, there has been <a3_0>an increase<a3_0/> in this area of employment throughout the country.
